Patient History.Birth: The patient was the second child of nonconsanguineous parents who was born after an uneventful pregnancy of 42 weeks.
Patient History.Family History: Positive family history of minicore myopathy (his sister died with this condition at age 5 due to aspiration).

Initial Findings.Congenital Hypotonia: At birth, early findings comprised congenital hypotonia.
Initial Findings.Facial Features: Low facial expression, low-set ears, facies myopathica.
Initial Findings.Swallowing Problems: Diagnosed with swallowing problems and gastroesophageal reflux.

Muscle Biopsy.Initial Biopsy: The initial histological findings suggested a possible multi/minicore disease.
Muscle Biopsy.Second Biopsy: The biopsy results showed the characteristic picture of central core disease: electron microscopy detected abnormal, large mitochondria with crystalline inclusions and biochemical evidence of severe mitochondrial dysfunction.

Genetic Findings.RYR1 Mutation: A compound heterozygous RYR1 mutation in complementary DNA (cDNA) was found.

Physical Development.Motor Development: No motor development was observed with regular physiotherapy.
Physical Development.Age 9 Years: The boy could not sit up, raise his arms above the level of the hips, hold a pen, or stand due to his severe, generalized muscle weakness and contractures.

Physical Signs.Skeletal Features: Kyphoscoliosis in addition to joint contractures, presenting foremost in his hips and knees.
Physical Signs.Muscle Anomalies: No extraocular muscle anomalies and no exercise-induced myalgia.

Biochemical and Genetic Analysis.Complex Deficiencies: Complex deficiencies I, II, III, IV.
